title: Invariant Styles
narrative:
This test demonstrates how various pairs of different styles
    produce identical component states as well as identical
    images when rendered into a BufferedImage.

features.id: Diagonally linear gradients can be invariant in certain cases. [0]

extraInfo:
This test demonstrates how various pairs of different gradient styles 
            produce identical images when rendered into a BufferedImage.
            More specifically we examine diagonal linear gradients.
            Diagonally linear menus that a gradient transitions from one corner
            of a component to the opposite corner.

blocks.text:
We first set the UI scaling factor to simulate a platform with higher DPI.
            So when your screen has a higher pixel density then this factor
            is used by SwingTree to ensure that the UI is upscaled accordingly! 
            Please note that the line below only exists for testing purposes, 
            SwingTree will determine a suitable 
            scaling factor for the current system automatically for you,
            so you do not have to specify this factor manually.
We declare to variables for storing pairs of identical widgets with different styles.
We create two widgets with different styles.
We render the two widgets into a BufferedImage.
They both have the expected size:
The images are identical even though they have different styles:
We create another pair of widgets with opposite gradient transitions.
We render the two widgets into a BufferedImage.
They both have the expected size:
The images are identical even though they have different styles:
We test this using the following scaling values:

features.id: Vertically and horizontally linear gradients can be invariant in certain cases. [0]

extraInfo:
This test demonstrates how various pairs of different styles 
            describing linear gradients produce identical images when rendered into a BufferedImage.
            Their invariant emerges from the order of the colors and the direction of the gradients
            transitioning from one color to the other being reversed.

features.id: Two labels with the same font style configuration will have equal font objects. [0]

blocks.text: Two labels with the same font style configuration
We build the two labels and also create a plain reference label:
We unpack the font objects from the labels.
The first two labels have the same font object.
The third label on the other hand has a different font object.
We test the following font configurations:

styler:
{f -> f.size(82)
           .family("Noto Sans")
           .weight(1.25)
           .color(Color.BLUE)
           .noise(noise -> noise
               .colors(Color.DARK_GRAY, Color.CYAN)
               .function(UI.NoiseType.SMOOTH_SPOTS)
               .scale(1.15)
           )
           .backgroundGradient(grad -> grad
               .colors(Color.GREEN, Color.MAGENTA, Color.ORANGE)
               .boundary(UI.ComponentBoundary.CENTER_TO_CONTENT)
               .span(UI.Span.BOTTOM_TO_TOP)
               .type(UI.GradientType.CONIC)
               .focus(26,16)
           )
    }

features.id: The view state hash code function on the SingTree internal ComponentExtension hashes view related state. [0]

blocks.text: We build the actual components of the UI declarations:
Initially, the component hashes are 0, because the components have no size!
We change one of the size dimensions each...
The hashes are still 0, because the component is not visible.
We change both size dimensions...
We calculate the hash codes of the two components again:
The hash codes are no longer 0 (or at least it should be super unlikely).
The hash codes are equal or not depending on the expected result.
We test the following UI declarations:
